description: Late Middle English, from Low German fommeln or Dutch fommelen.
Or, perhaps from a Scandinavian/North Germanic source; compare Old Norse fálma, Swedish fumla, Danish fumle, German fummeln.

The ultimate origin for either could perhaps be imitative of fumbling.  Or, from Proto-Indo-European *pal- (“to shake, swing”), see also Latin palpo (“I pat, touch softly”), and possibly Proto-West Germanic *fōlijan (“to feel”).

entries.meaning: (sports, American football, Canadian football) A ball etc. that has been dropped by accident.

verbs.description: fumble (third-person singular simple present fumbles, present participle fumbling, simple past and past participle fumbled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To handle nervously or awkwardly.
examples: Waiting for the interview, he fumbled with his tie.
He fumbled the key into the lock.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To grope awkwardly in trying to find something
examples: He fumbled his way to the light-switch.
He fumbled through his prepared speech.

entries.meaning: To grope about in perplexity; to seek awkwardly.
(transitive, intransitive, sports) To drop a ball or a baton etc. by accident.
To handle much; to play childishly; to turn over and over.
(slang, obsolete) Of a man, to sexually underperform. [16th to 18th c.]
(Britain) A dessert similar to a cross between a fool and a crumble.
